newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian trade sees LME copper/zinc rising further.
newsitem.headline: Asian trade sees LME copper/zinc rising further.

text.p: London Metal Exchange (LME) copper and zinc prices are tipped to post further gains later on Friday, but the red metal is seen ripe for a correction in the next few days, Far East traders said.
"The trend is up, but copper is due for a big correction," one dealer said. "I think it (three month) will reach US$2,560-$2,570 (a tonne) before it comes down."
Three month copper was seen by regional dealers at 0330 GMT at $2,505/10 a tonne, slightly easier from the late London quote on Thursday of $2,507/10.

Metal brokers Brandeis said that copper continued "to look robust but a pullback is now overdue with the market needing to confirm support in the $2,470/90 area before mustering sufficient strength to attain the $2,550 target."
"Copper needs to go down. It's badly over-extended," another dealer said.
The current price of the red metal has drawn interest from Chinese merchants "who are looking at making some sales soon," a trader said.

Zinc prices, on the other hand, are expected to approach the $1,400 a tonne barrier later on Friday after hitting a high of $1,370 on the LME on Thursday -- the highest level since September 1992. Zinc eventually closed at $1,364.
"There'll be a lot of selling when zinc hits $1,385, especially from the Chinese," one dealer said, adding some of the Chinese were already unloading material in Asian trade.
"The price may be a bit overdone. I'm very bullish on zinc, but I'm surprised it got here so soon. There's still plenty of zinc in Asia," another dealer said.
Traders estimate about 15,000-20,000 tonnes of zinc remain off-warrant in warehouses in Singapore and that an additional 5,000 tonnes of zinc from China will arrive in the city-state this week.
Three month zinc was quoted by the trade at 0330 GMT at $1,362/66 a tonne.
